intro: Androsace gorodkovii subsp. semiperennis, commonly known as the alpine mouse-ear, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Gesneriaceae and is characterized by its dense, rosette-like foliage composed of small, rounded leaves. The plant produces clusters of delicate, bell-shaped flowers in shades of pink or white, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky slopes. Due to its unique appearance and habitat, it is of interest to botanists and horticulturists alike.
